A Crucial Time For Planning
The difficulties inherent in developing a
"master plan" outlining the direction and
goals of a university arc tremendous
However, the financial crunch that is currently impinging on Hopkins and which promises to remain in the future makes such
planning imperative. With Hopkins' 1984-89
"Capital Campaign" approaching, both the
School of Arts and Sciences and the School
of Engineering were asked to prepare reports
for the fund raising drive. These reports, still
in the process of being completed;serve two
functions. They depict Hopkins as an attractive investment for business and industry,
and they allow the schools to state their needs
and goals. However the divisions must first
decide these needs and define these goals.
The reports provide an excellent opportunity
to establish a clear direction for the
Homewood divisions of the University.
The Engineering School has the easiest
task. The Engineering division is rapidly
growing and will continue to expand. It expects to gain additional faculty and students.
The preliminary draft of the Engineering
School report is upbeat; it will entice potential investors. Yet the preliminary draft has
elicted some faculty complaints. Some have
argued that it does not establish clear
priorities. However the lack of clear
priorities will probably not hurt the
Engineering School during the Capital Campaign. The division produces students who
have the knowledge of modern technology
that industry needs. The advantages of industry investment are obvious. The Arts and
Sciences division has much more serious
problems.
The Arts and Sciences division is not

growing, and as a whole does not expect the
do so in the near future. Due to this prospect
and because the advantages for industry investment are not obvious, the need for a
coherent, comprehensive plan is paramount.
In this respect, the Christ Committee report
for the Arts and Sciences division leaves
much to be desired. This is reflected by the
extent of faculty criticism. The report fails
to convey any sense of where the school
wants to go during the next decade. In
outlining priorities, it eschews politically sensitive issues. Certainly everybody favors
library improvements, visiting professorships
and post-doctoral fellowships. But as
Political Economy Professor Bela Balassa
stressed at last week's General Assembly
meeting, a much more serious problem lies
in the declining quality of many Arts and
Sciences departments. However, once one
begins to target certain areas of need,
political tensions invariably mount.
Although the Christ report does emphasize
important issues such as financial aid and
an effort to concentrate on astrophysics (an
obvious choice for growth because of the
presence of the Space Telescope Institute),
it must go much further in establishing
priorities and general goals for the division.
Otherwise the division may face ten more
years of what Physics Professor J.C. Walker
termed, "flubbing around as usual." For
the Arts and Sciences division, the task of effective planning in a no-growth environment
is difficult yet essential in terms of efficiency and selling the division. For the sake of
the University's future, it is hoped that the
Christ Committee will not end up as another
opportunity lost.

Congress And Student Aid
As far as students are concerned, probably
the most important issue on the national
political scene is financial aid. The effect of'
this week's elections on student aid prospects
are likely to be positive. Although it is
unlikely that the new Congress will be able
to reverse the trends of the past two years,
further efforts to reduce federal assistance
will likely be stymied.
In preparation for the 1983 budget, the
Reagan administration had proposed severe
cutbacks in funds for National Direct Student Loans, Supplementary Educational Opportunity Grants and funds for Work Study.

There was even talk of eliminating
Guaranteed Student Loans. These programs
now appear to be safe.
The likelihood for any increase in federal
aid for students is minimal and would probably occur only if a decrease in military expenditures allowed additional funds to be
diverted to social programs. The chances of
this occurring remain small. Nevertheless, the
good news is that it seems as though for at
least two years, the conservative trends that
have wiped away student aid benefits have
been ground to a halt.

at the Clarence Clemons concert due to poor

People who have seen Clemons in concert

around who would be willing to pay seven

Speaker and Concert Committee chairpersons must not be overlooked. The Student
Council must be more careful of its appointments in the future.

DMSO Study Gets Underway
BY BILL BERNSTEIN
The Union Memorial Sports
Medicine Center is currently
conducting a study of the use of
DMSO for sprained ankles.
The study, sanctioned by the
FDA, is one of the first comprehensive investigations of
DMSO in Maryland.
The Sports Medicine Center
is looking for participants in the
study. Males and females 18
and over are eligible to take
part, but must report to the
Emergency Room at Union
Memorial Hospital within 36
hours of the injury. Since the
study requires several visits,
participants will receive
renumeration of $100 upon
completion of treatment.
DMSO, dimethyl sulfoxide,
has been touted by many as a
"wonder drug" which heals a
lot of injuries, including sprained ankles, at a remarkable
speed. There is still uncertainty, however, about how DMSO
works and what its side effects
are
DMSO is believed to work by
absorbing the fluid causing the
swelling, alleviating the pressure caused by the inflammation, and therefore ending the
pain. The drug remains a
mystery, though, in that it acts
differently on different individuals. The effects of DMSO
vary greatly from person to person. The drug is even unpredictable when used by the same
person more than once; it may
relieve pain one week and fail
to do so the next.
In the past, DMSO users
have reported many side effects. The most common side

effect is a strong garlic taste and
body odor. Also DMSO may,
depending on skin tolerance,
cause irritation to the area
where it is applied. It is believed that higher concentrations of
the drug are more effective in
relieving the pain, but they may
cause more irritation. The area
to which the DMSO is to be applied must be cleaned thoroughly before the drug iS used.
This is because DMSO is a
strong solvent and is able to
penetrate the skin rapidly.
Thus, it is able to transport dirt
particles present on the surface
of the skin through the skin and
into the body.
In addition, although no
cases of toxicity have been
reported, there is (as there is
with any drug) a possibility of
an allergic reaction.
Most DMSO users have
reported only the strong garlic
taste and odor as side effects.
Many have described the side
effects as minor compared to
'the benefits of the drug. Sports
figures who have made extensive successful use of DMSO include Alberto Salazar and Jim
Palmer.

to the Sports Medicine Center

A Crucial Time For Planning
The difficulties inherent in developing a
"master plan" outlining the direction and
goals of a university arc tremendous
However, the financial crunch that is currently impinging on Hopkins and which promises to remain in the future makes such
planning imperative. With Hopkins' 1984-89
"Capital Campaign" approaching, both the
School of Arts and Sciences and the School
of Engineering were asked to prepare reports
for the fund raising drive. These reports, still
in the process of being completed;serve two
functions. They depict Hopkins as an attractive investment for business and industry,
and they allow the schools to state their needs
and goals. However the divisions must first
decide these needs and define these goals.
The reports provide an excellent opportunity
to establish a clear direction for the
Homewood divisions of the University.
The Engineering School has the easiest
task. The Engineering division is rapidly
growing and will continue to expand. It expects to gain additional faculty and students.
The preliminary draft of the Engineering
School report is upbeat; it will entice potential investors. Yet the preliminary draft has
elicted some faculty complaints. Some have
argued that it does not establish clear
priorities. However the lack of clear
priorities will probably not hurt the
Engineering School during the Capital Campaign. The division produces students who
have the knowledge of modern technology
that industry needs. The advantages of industry investment are obvious. The Arts and
Sciences division has much more serious
problems.
The Arts and Sciences division is not

growing, and as a whole does not expect the
do so in the near future. Due to this prospect
and because the advantages for industry investment are not obvious, the need for a
coherent, comprehensive plan is paramount.
In this respect, the Christ Committee report
for the Arts and Sciences division leaves
much to be desired. This is reflected by the
extent of faculty criticism. The report fails
to convey any sense of where the school
wants to go during the next decade. In
outlining priorities, it eschews politically sensitive issues. Certainly everybody favors
library improvements, visiting professorships
and post-doctoral fellowships. But as
Political Economy Professor Bela Balassa
stressed at last week's General Assembly
meeting, a much more serious problem lies
in the declining quality of many Arts and
Sciences departments. However, once one
begins to target certain areas of need,
political tensions invariably mount.
Although the Christ report does emphasize
important issues such as financial aid and
an effort to concentrate on astrophysics (an
obvious choice for growth because of the
presence of the Space Telescope Institute),
it must go much further in establishing
priorities and general goals for the division.
Otherwise the division may face ten more
years of what Physics Professor J.C. Walker
termed, "flubbing around as usual." For
the Arts and Sciences division, the task of effective planning in a no-growth environment
is difficult yet essential in terms of efficiency and selling the division. For the sake of
the University's future, it is hoped that the
Christ Committee will not end up as another
opportunity lost.

Congress And Student Aid
As far as students are concerned, probably
the most important issue on the national
political scene is financial aid. The effect of'
this week's elections on student aid prospects
are likely to be positive. Although it is
unlikely that the new Congress will be able
to reverse the trends of the past two years,
further efforts to reduce federal assistance
will likely be stymied.
In preparation for the 1983 budget, the
Reagan administration had proposed severe
cutbacks in funds for National Direct Student Loans, Supplementary Educational Opportunity Grants and funds for Work Study.

There was even talk of eliminating
Guaranteed Student Loans. These programs
now appear to be safe.
The likelihood for any increase in federal
aid for students is minimal and would probably occur only if a decrease in military expenditures allowed additional funds to be
diverted to social programs. The chances of
this occurring remain small. Nevertheless, the
good news is that it seems as though for at
least two years, the conservative trends that
have wiped away student aid benefits have
been ground to a halt.

BY BILL BERNSTEIN
The Union Memorial Sports
Medicine Center is currently
conducting a study of the use of
DMSO for sprained ankles.
The study, sanctioned by the
FDA, is one of the first comprehensive investigations of
DMSO in Maryland.
The Sports Medicine Center
is looking for participants in the
study. Males and females 18
and over are eligible to take
part, but must report to the
Emergency Room at Union
Memorial Hospital within 36
hours of the injury. Since the
study requires several visits,
participants will receive
renumeration of $100 upon
completion of treatment.
DMSO, dimethyl sulfoxide,
has been touted by many as a
"wonder drug" which heals a
lot of injuries, including sprained ankles, at a remarkable
speed. There is still uncertainty, however, about how DMSO
works and what its side effects
are
DMSO is believed to work by
absorbing the fluid causing the
swelling, alleviating the pressure caused by the inflammation, and therefore ending the
pain. The drug remains a
mystery, though, in that it acts
differently on different individuals. The effects of DMSO
vary greatly from person to person. The drug is even unpredictable when used by the same
person more than once; it may
relieve pain one week and fail
to do so the next.
In the past, DMSO users
have reported many side effects. The most common side

effect is a strong garlic taste and
body odor. Also DMSO may,
depending on skin tolerance,
cause irritation to the area
where it is applied. It is believed that higher concentrations of
the drug are more effective in
relieving the pain, but they may
cause more irritation. The area
to which the DMSO is to be applied must be cleaned thoroughly before the drug iS used.
This is because DMSO is a
strong solvent and is able to
penetrate the skin rapidly.
Thus, it is able to transport dirt
particles present on the surface
of the skin through the skin and
into the body.
In addition, although no
cases of toxicity have been
reported, there is (as there is
with any drug) a possibility of
an allergic reaction.
Most DMSO users have
reported only the strong garlic
taste and odor as side effects.
Many have described the side
effects as minor compared to
'the benefits of the drug. Sports
figures who have made extensive successful use of DMSO include Alberto Salazar and Jim
